Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: PROBLEM OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number that can keep track of theproblems that have arisen in the sample analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ACTIVITY SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for an activity set.
Column Comment.5: ANALYSIS PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is aproblem with the sample analysis.
Column Comment.6: BUSINESS ASSOCIATE PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether ornot there is a problem with the business associate.
Column Comment.7: REFERENCE ANALYSIS CONFIDENCE TYPE: The level of confidence or certaintyfor an analysis value. Various systems for measurement are defined in literature, andmay be text based (CERTAIN, PROBABLE, UNCERTAIN) or number based. Thisvalue tends to be subjective, and indicates the level of trust the analyst has in theresult.
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first comes into effect.
Column Comment.9: EQUIPMENT PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is aproblem with a particular piece of equipment.
Column Comment.10: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row is no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.11: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.12: METHOD PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is aproblem with the method for sample analysis.
Column Comment.13: PERCENT OF SAMPLE: The percent of sample required in the sample analysis. Ifthere is not enough sample this may very well effect the quality of the sampleanalysis.
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: PROBLEM DESCRIPTION: A narrative description about the problem that has arisenin the sample analysis.
Column Comment.16: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM RESULT: The type of consequence that wasthe outcome of the problem described. For example, results may be inaccurate, or atest may be destroyed, or results may show anomalous values.
Column Comment.17: PROBLEM RESULT DESCRIPTION: Narrative comments about the result orconsequences of this problem.
Column Comment.18: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM SEVERITY: A valid type of severity related to aproblem encountered during analysis. The severity may range from inconsequentialto invalidating the results of a study.
Column Comment.19: PROBLEM SEVERITY DESCRIPTION: Narrative comments about how serious thisproblem was to the results of the study.
Column Comment.20: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM TYPE: This reference list contains a list of thevalid problems that can and are associated with laboratory analysis. Problems mayrelate to equipment calibration errors, sample contamination, incorrect proceduresused, technical error etc.
Column Comment.21: PPDM COLUMN NAME: The name of a column that has an association with thislevel of classification system.
Column Comment.22: PPDM GUID: This value may be used to provide a global unique identifier for this rowof data. If used, optional PPDM NOT NULL constraints should be created.
Column Comment.23: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema.
Column Comment.24: PPDM TABLE NAME: The name of a table that has an association with this level of aclassification system. This may be used in conjunction with an appropriate foreignkey from the table that is referenced, or may be used generically in combination withthe
Column Comment.25: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.26: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM RESOLUTION METHOD: The method used toresolve a problem encountered during analysis. Could include re-running thesamples, calibrating equipment, collecting a new sample batch, altering parametersand so on.
Column Comment.27: RESOLUTION METHOD DESCRIPTION: Narrative remarks about how this problemwas resolved, it was actually resolved.
Column Comment.28: RESOLUTION STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number that is assigned toeach step in the resolution of a problem. This numbering of steps can be used tounderstand what was actually done in the resolution of the problem and ultimatelycan be used to see if the problem could be resolved more efficiently.
Column Comment.29: RESOLVED BY BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for thebusiness associate that resolved the problem.
Column Comment.30: SAMPLE PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is aproblem with the sample.
Column Comment.31: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.32: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column is asufficient method to keep track of what is done in the sample analysis. However, ifthe requirement for more complicated tracking such as two steps occurringsimultaneously or if steps are needed to be added to the initial procedure, use thetwo columns STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 in the tableANL_STEP_XREF.
Column Comment.33: VALID PROBLEM OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifier for a recognized typeof problem for an analysis method. Use this column to compare the problemsidentified during analysis with the kinds of problem generally found. Optional.
Column Comment.34: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.36: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.38: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
